ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Greater understanding of what it means to be an architect, and the different forms of thinking that are required. Architecture is a much broader area of study than most people realize, and this course shows why and how.

I learned so much! this is the first arch course I've taken that was more of a studio, and even though we were online, I still learned so much either using the Rhino, the adobe suite, or architectural concepts and practice.

I learned a great deal about working creatively, thinking in an outside-of-the-box manner, and approaching problems from multiple angles. I also started learning how to use Photoshop, InDesign, Rhino, and Ilustrator.
ARCH 200 is an architectural studio course based around four major projects. Throughout these assignments, students learn programs such as Rhino, Photoshop, and InDesign.
I created a better understanding of space and how humans interact with it.

I learned a lot about how to design and draw in different types of ways. The various projects encouraged me to use a wide variety of tools, computer and otherwise, to develop visual representations of ideas. I also thought about various questions of politics and space and power in how they relate to both the built environment and our representations of it.

I learned about architectural conventions of scale, elevation, section, and plan.  I was introduced to software programs for documentation: Photoshop, inDesign, Rhino, and Adobe Illustrator.  Three were untold insights regarding ways to conceive of space and ways to represent space.
was challenged to make compelling narratives with open-ended projects

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures were 10/10, Bimal is amazing. Could be improved by working with peers in-person lol.

Being online, it was very different than having an in person studio. Much of are assignments were changed to fit an online medium, but even then I still had a great deal of fun working on the projects and seeing what all my other classmates also produced given our scenario.

The greatest strengths of this course are the assignments and they way they build upon each other and successively push you, as well as the support from Professor Mendis and especially the TAs. The weakness are the lectures, which, while interesting, sometimes felt somewhat irrelevantI feel like I didn't really take much away from them in general. Another weakness is that all the softwares are introduced in such rapid succession and so quickly. Even now, I don't feel entirely competent when it comes to using any of them. Finally, there was also very little transparency regarding grades throughout the semesterwe didn't receive formal grades on any of the assignments, which made it very difficult to tell how you were doing in the class.

This course was a fantastic introduction to architectural design, and allowed students to bring their personal interests into each assignment. There's a lot of room to experiment and be creative in the course, as well as opportunities to learn computer programs that are otherwise confusing. However, the expectations for assignments were a little unclear at times, leaving students lost on how to approach a given project. I think that more clarity on expectations and project rubrics would benefit the success of students greatly.

The projects were really fun and interesting! It was great to be thrown a challenge and to have to do it. It was also great to have so much guidance from the TFs at every stage of the process. The lectures sometimes felt a bit long. They were at lunch time, and sometimes we would both have a lecture and have a discussion of different students' projects, which the students hadn't prepared for. Since we had so much other class time, it felt to me that these could have been reduced.
This course was all strengths.  The format of virtual lectures won't be repeated.  That caused some hardship.  Otherwise it was highly fulfilling.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having it in person really is just probably much better. It allows for the students to collaborate more as well and that's something I feel we missed out on.

Obviously this is a difficult class to conduct onlinebeing a studio class, I'm sure there's a lot we were missing out on by meeting entirely through Zoom. That said, lectures and tutorials over Zoom worked, for the most part, and I'm not sure how you could improve or replicate the studio experience any more than was already done (through Zoom crits, the Miro board, etc.).
The Zoom sections were totally fine, and it was good to have to present our material in video form carefully. On the other hand, when Zoom classes feel long, they really feel long.

The slide lectures translated quite well to the online format.  Regrettably, there was little class discussion. Students rarely spoke to each other.  Rather, we each took turns speaking to the professors and TAs.  This was not particular to this class. It happened in all my Spring 2021 classes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is not as rewarding as Architecture 150 or 280 so it's a valuable course if you're trying to decide if the Architecture major is right for you, but not if you're a non-major hoping for something like 150 or 280.
Absolutely. This is a great class. If you have any interest in architecture, take this course!

I would definitely recommend this course, both to those planning to major in Architecture and to those who just want a class that challenges them to work more artistically and creatively than the standard Yale course.
Yes, very fun to work on hands-on project and if you are interested in architecture.
I would recommend this course to any student wanting to try their hand at architectural design and an organized studio course.
Yes, this is an extremely fun class that lets you be creative and unique while learning basic skills of modeling.

Yes, if they want to devote a lot of time to learning to design things in the built environment! It was great fun, and a very big time commitment (if you chose to make it one). I think it was only worth it because I put in so much time, and if I hadn't, I don't think it would've been a very interesting class.
Yes.  This class was fun and interesting.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had section with our TA's twice a week
live sections
Weekly virtual section
Live virtual seminar as well
There were also 2x-a-week live virtual sections, one to explain techniques and one to discuss our projects. I attended the technique explaining ones virtually as I had a conflict.
Live virtual section
section
